statement:
Let $G,H$ be groups, and let $f \colon G \to H$ be a group homomorphism.
Then $f$ is injective if and only if ${\operatorname{Ker}}(f)=\{e_G\}$,
where $e_G$ is the identity element of $G$, and ${\operatorname{Ker}}$
denotes the kernel of $f$ (see also Kernel of a group homomorphism).

First assume that $f$ is injective (i.e.
$f(g_1)=f(g_2) \Rightarrow g_1=g_2$). Recall that:
$${\operatorname{Ker}}(f)=\{ g\in G : f(g)=e_H \}$$ where $e_H$ is the
identity element of $H$. Since $f$ is a group homomorphism, it follows
that $f(e_G)=e_H$. Let $g\in {\operatorname{Ker}}(f)$, then
$f(g)=e_H=f(e_G)$, which implies that $g=e_G$, by the injectivity of
$f$. Thus ${\operatorname{Ker}}(f)=\{ e_G \}$.

For the converse, we assume that ${\operatorname{Ker}}(f)=\{ e_G \}$ and
suppose that $f(g_1)=f(g_2)$, for some $g_1,g_2 \in G$. Since $f$ is a
homomorphism:
$$f(g_1)=f(g_2) \Rightarrow f(g_1)\cdot f(g_2)^{-1}=e_H \Rightarrow f(g_1\cdot g_2^{-1})=e_H$$
Thus $g_1\cdot g_2^{-1} \in {\operatorname{Ker}}(f)$, and the kernel is
trivial so $g_1\cdot g_2^{-1}=e_G$, therefore $g_1=g_2$.
names: a group homomorphism is injective iff the kernel is trivial
